Basilisk (BB).name: Basilisk (BB)
Basilisk (BB).publicNotes: A basilisk is an eight-legged reptile that can turn creatures to stone just by looking at them.

action->Petrifying Glance.name: Petrifying Glance
action->Petrifying Glance.description:
When a creature the basilisk can see within 30 feet starts its turn, the basilisk can use its reaction to glance at the creature.

The creature must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:20] save. If it fails, it gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} condition for 1 minute as its body slowly stiffens.

action->Petrifying Gaze.name: Petrifying Gaze
action->Petrifying Gaze.description:
The basilisk stares at a creature it can see within 30 feet. If the creature can see the basilisk, that creature must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:22] save.

If it fails and hasn't already gained the slowed condition from Petrifying Glance or this ability, it gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} condition. If the creature fails this save when it already has the slowed condition from this ability or Petrifying Glance, the creature is permanently turned to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dTwPJuKgBQCMxixg]{Stone}.

A creature petrified in this manner that is coated with fresh basilisk blood is instantly restored to flesh. A single basilisk contains enough blood to coat up to 2 creatures in this manner.

Brine Shark (BB).name: Brine Shark (BB)
Brine Shark (BB).publicNotes:
Water elementals roam the endless oceans of the Plane of Water. They can be brought to the world with summoning magic or through natural disasters like floods or hurricanes. Though water elementals can be very destructive, they aren't always malicious. Just as water can bring life to those in need, its waves can pound shores and its rains flood cities. Water elementals are similarly difficult to predict.

Brine sharks take forms resembling sharks made entirely of water and are fierce, but among the weaker water elementals. They often slip into mortal oceans, competing with natural predators or even joining schools of flesh and blood sharks.

action->Deep Plunge.name: Deep Plunge
action->Deep Plunge.description: The brine shark dives straight down into the water, swimming up to 100 feet in a straight vertical line. It can use this ability while @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbing} a creature.

action->Grab.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.Tkd8sH4pwFIPzqTr]

When the brine shark succeeds at its jaws Strike, it can use this action immediately after to attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} the target. This Grapple doesn't apply or count toward the shark's multiple attack penalty.

Bugbear Prowler (BB).name: Bugbear Prowler (BB)
Bugbear Prowler (BB).publicNotes: These stealthy and cruel creatures delight in spreading fear and tormenting their victims. Bugbears are the monsters lurking in the closet and hiding under the bed. Preying on remote farmsteads, bugbears reveal their presence with thumps in the night or creaking boards, inspiring dread, suspicion, and fear in those they torment.

weapon->Longsword.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.LJdbVTOZog39EEbi]

Longswords can be one-edged or two-edged swords. Their blades are heavy and they're between 3 and 4 feet in length.

action->Bushwhack.name: Bushwhack
action->Bushwhack.description: The bugbear prowler Strides up to 10 feet and attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} a creature that can't see them and doesn't know where they are. If the bugbear succeeds, they also deal damage from their fist Strike to that creature.

action->Mauler.name: Mauler
action->Mauler.description: The bugbear prowler gains a +3 circumstance bonus to damage rolls against creatures they have @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}.

Caligni Dancer (BB).name: Caligni Dancer (BB)
Caligni Dancer (BB).publicNotes: Caligni lurk in subterranean cities, and they relish the chance to creep above ground at night to steal resources, spy on surface dwellers, or simply cause mischief.

action->Light Blindness.name: Light Blindness
action->Light Blindness.description: When first exposed to bright light, the caligni can't see until the end of their next turn. All squares are difficult terrain for them, and they take a -4 status penalty to Perception. If they try to attack a creature, the attack fails unless they succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:11]. Light doesn't blind them again for 1 hour.

action->Final Dance.name: Final Dance
action->Final Dance.description: When a caligni dancer dies, their body dissolves into a swirl of darkness and light. All creatures within @Template[emanation|distance:10]{10 feet} must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:17] save or take a -2 circumstance penalty on all attack rolls for 1 round.

action->Sneak Attack.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.AWvNPE4U0kEJSL1T]

The caligni dancer deals an additional 1d6 damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

action->Final Fate.description: When a caligni hunter dies, their body explodes. All creatures within @Template[emanation|distance:20]{20 feet} must take @Damage[5d6[fire]]. Each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:19|basic] save.

action->Darkening Poison.name: Darkening Poison

action->Final Night.name: Final Night
action->Final Night.description: When a caligni skulker dies, their body dissolves fog of inky darkness. All light sources within @Template[emanation|distance:20]{20 feet} are extinguished. Any light spells in the area go out for 1 round.

action->Darkening Poison.name: Darkening Poison
action->Darkening Poison.description: The next time the skulker deals damage with a dagger Strike, the target must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:16|traits:damaging-effect] save or take @Damage[1d8[poison]] damage and treat all creatures as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} for 1 round.

Central Spears (BB).name: Central Spears (BB)
Central Spears (BB).disable: A hero must succeed at a @Check[thievery|dc:18|traits:hazard|name:Disable Mechanism] check on the triggering floor tiles or the wall sockets in the western wall.

action->Spear Barrage.name: Spear Barrage
action->Spear Barrage.description: When a creature moves into any of the squares in the outlined area, the trap shoots three spears from the western wall. It makes one ranged Strike against the westernmost creature in each row.

Cinder Rat (BB).name: Cinder Rat (BB)
Cinder Rat (BB).publicNotes:
Fire elementals are destructive manifestations of the Plane of Fire. They sometimes come to the world in powerful places of heat and flame where elemental vortexes form, such as in volcanoes.

Cinder rats are oversized rodents made of smoldering charcoal and elemental fire. Noxious fumes continually bellow from their flaming flesh. Much like terrestrial rats, cinder rats seek out secluded dens and can quickly multiply in number if left unchecked.

action->Smoke Vision.name: Smoke Vision
action->Smoke Vision.description: The cinder rat ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from smoke.

action->Fetid Fumes.name: Fetid Fumes
action->Fetid Fumes.description: A cloud of smoke surrounds the cinder rat. All creatures within @Template[emanation|distance:5]{5 feet}, including the cinder rat, gain the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from this smoke. A creature that comes within 5 feet of the cinder rat or begins its turn within 5 feet must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:22] save or take a -1 status penalty to all checks and DCs for 1 round (Use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}).

Doppelganger (BB).name: Doppelganger (BB)
Doppelganger (BB).publicNotes: Doppelgangers can transform into perfect copies of other creatures but have indeterminate forms in their natural states.

action->End the Charade.name: End the Charade
action->End the Charade.description:
When the doppelganger is transformed with Change Shape and another creature moves adjacent to them or uses a Strike or another hostile action against them, the doppelganger can use its reaction to revert to its natural form and make a Strike against that creature.

If the creature was unaware the doppelganger was in disguise, that creature has the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition against this Strike.

action->Change Shape.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.eQM5hQ1W3d1uen97]

The doppelganger takes on the specific appearance of any Small or Medium humanoid it has seen. This doesn't change the doppelganger's Stride speed or their attack and damage bonuses with their Strikes, but it might change the damage type their Strikes deal (typically to bludgeoning).

action->Mind Reading.name: Mind Reading
action->Mind Reading.description: The doppelganger attempts to read the surface thoughts of one creature within 30 feet. The target resists if it succeeds at a @Check[will|dc:21] save.

spell->Magic Weapon.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.TFitdEOpQC4SzKQQ]
Magic Weapon
spell->Magic Weapon.target: 1 weapon that is unattended or wielded by you or a willing ally

shield->Shield.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.Yr9yCuJiAlFh3QEB]
Shield
shield->Shield.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.Yr9yCuJiAlFh3QEB]

A shield has 20 Hit Points. If a shield ever takes 10 damage or more, it becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6dNUvdb1dhToNDj3]{Broken}. A broken shield can't be used for @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.xjGwis0uaC2305pm]{Raise a Shield} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.jM72TjJ965jocBV8]{Shield Block}, but you can still @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.bT3skovyLUtP22ME]{Repair} it. If the shield loses all 20 Hit Points, it is completely destroyed.

equipment->Religious Symbol (Wooden).description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.plplsXJsqrdqNQVI]

This piece of wood or silver is emblazoned with an image representing a deity. Some divine spellcasters, such as clerics, can use a religious symbol of their deity as a divine focus to use certain abilities and cast some spells. A religious symbol must be held in one hand to use it.

action->Light Blindness.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.I0HYG0ctCLP5JRsW]

All squares are difficult terrain for them, and they take a -4 status penalty to Perception. If they try to attack a creature, the attack fails unless they succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:11]. Light doesn't blind them again for 1 hour.

action->Shield Block.description:

If she @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.xjGwis0uaC2305pm]{Raised a Shield} since her last turn, the priestess can spend her reaction to block a Strike. Reduce the Strike's damage by 5, but then she and the shield both take the remaining damage, possibly @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6dNUvdb1dhToNDj3]{Breaking} or destroying the shield.

Drow Sneak (BB).name: Drow Sneak (BB)
Drow Sneak (BB).publicNotes: Loners at heart, drow sneaks trust no one-least of all fellow drow. These drow rely on awareness and adaptation to survive the cutthroat nature of their society.

action->Light Blindness.description:

Light doesn't blind them again for 1 hour.

action->Quick Draw.name: Quick Draw
action->Quick Draw.description: The drow rogue draws a weapon using the Interact action, then Strikes with that weapon.

Drow Warrior (BB).name: Drow Warrior (BB)
Drow Warrior (BB).publicNotes: Drow are the descendants of elves corrupted by a great evil when they fled deep underground long ago.

Light doesn't blind them again for 1 hour.

action->Quick Draw.name: Quick Draw
action->Quick Draw.description: The drow warrior draws a weapon using the Interact action, then Strikes with that weapon.

action->Skewer.name: Skewer
action->Skewer.description: The drow warrior Strikes with their rapier, and they gain a +1 circumstance bonus to the attack roll. If they succeed, the target takes @Damage[1d6[bleed]].

Envenomed Lock (BB).name: Envenomed Lock (BB)
Envenomed Lock (BB).description: A spring-loaded, poisoned spine is hidden near the keyhole of a lock. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disabling} or breaking the trap doesn't disable or break the lock.
Envenomed Lock (BB).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:17|traits:hazard|name:Disable the Spring Mechanism] on the spring mechanism

action->Spring.name: Spring
action->Spring.description: When a creature tries to unlock or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H]{Pick the Lock}, a spine extends to attack that creature with a Spine attack.

Falling Ceiling (BB).name: Falling Ceiling (BB)
Falling Ceiling (BB).disable: A hero must succeed at a @Check[thievery|dc:18|traits:hazard|name:Prevent Blocks from Falling] check on the triggering square or the ceiling to prevent the stone blocks from falling.

action->Falling Stones.name: Falling Stones
action->Falling Stones.description: When a creature steps on the square closest to the north door, the trap drops blocks of stone all along the hallway. It makes one ranged Strike against each creature between the two doors.

Forest Troll (BB).name: Forest Troll (BB)
Forest Troll (BB).publicNotes: Forest trolls are dim-witted, gangly giants who stalk the fringes of civilization. They rely on their incredible strength to overpower foes with their vicious claws. A troll's endless hunger drives them to consume a variety of living creatures. Trolls stand anywhere from 12 to 16 feet tall, though they prefer to hunch to lull foes into a false sense of security.

action->Regeneration 20 (Deactivated by.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.lR9R5Vld8Eu2Dha5]
Regeneration 20 (Deactivated by Electricity or Fire)
action->Regeneration 20 (Deactivated by.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.lR9R5Vld8Eu2Dha5]

The troll regains 20 Hit Points at the start of their turn unless they've taken electricity or fire damage since their last turn. The troll can't die unless their regeneration is deactivated when they're reduced to 0 HP.

action->Easily Misled.name: Easily Misled
action->Easily Misled.description: The forest troll gets a -4 circumstance penalty to their Perception DC against deception checks.

action->Rend.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.3JOi2cMcGhT3eze1]

If the troll succeeds at two claw Strikes against the same creature in the same turn, they can use this ability to automatically deal claw Strike damage to that creature.

Gargoyle (BB).name: Gargoyle (BB)
Gargoyle (BB).publicNotes:
Gargoyles are monstrous hunters made entirely of stone. They look like decorative statues and use this as camouflage to hide in plain sight in cities during the day and descend upon unlucky pedestrians at night. Their most common form is that of a horned humanoid with batlike wings, but individual gargoyles vary a great deal, with some appearing more or less humanoid and others resembling something else entirely.

Gargoyles tend to be lone hunters, though sometimes they band into groups called wings for protection or sport.

action->Clawed Feet.name: Clawed Feet
action->Clawed Feet.description: If the gargoyle is flying and a creature moves into an adjacent square below them, the gargoyle can use their reaction to make a claw Strike against that creature.

action->Statue.name: Statue
action->Statue.description: Until the next time they use an action, the gargoyle appears to be a statue. A creature must succeed at a @Check[perception|dc:32] check to figure out that the statue is really a creature.

action->Site Bound.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.BcSlVpaN72LoQ5BV]
Site Bound
action->Site Bound.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.BcSlVpaN72LoQ5BV]

A ghost can stray no more than 120 feet from where it was killed or the place it haunts. Some are bound to items or creatures that were special to them rather than a location.

action->Incorporeal.name: Incorporeal
action->Incorporeal.description: A ghost has no body and can pass through physical objects, though it can't end its turn inside one. Most checks that use Strength and require a body, such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shove}, don't work against a ghost, and a ghost can't attempt such checks.

action->Rejuvenation.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.unR8VVR4yyRnsmnB]
Rejuvenation
action->Rejuvenation.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.unR8VVR4yyRnsmnB]

Setting right the injustice that led to the ghost's death allows it to move on to the afterlife. Otherwise, when destroyed, the ghost re-forms after [[/br 2d4 #Rejuvenation]]{2d4 days} within the location it's bound to, fully healed.

action->Frightful Moan.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.aiwlPSmNY9b6Psvd]
Frightful Moan
action->Frightful Moan.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.aiwlPSmNY9b6Psvd]

Each living creature within @Template[emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} who hears the ghost must attempt a @Check[will|dc:21] save. On a failure, a creature gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} condition (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3} on a critical failure).

On a success, a creature can't be affected by this ghost's Frightful Moan for 1 minute.

Ghoul Stalker (BB).name: Ghoul Stalker (BB)
Ghoul Stalker (BB).publicNotes: The flesh-eating undead, known as ghouls, haunt sinister locations such as lonely graveyards and ruined crypts, making meals of corpses. Legends say that those captured by ghouls hear foul whispers that curse them into craving raw meat, eventually turning them into ghouls.

action->Stench.name: Stench
action->Stench.description: A creature that comes within 10 feet of the ghoul and can smell the ghoul must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:14] save. On a failure, the creature takes a -1 status penalty to all checks and DCs until it uses an action to retch (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}). A creature that succeeds at its save isn't affected by any ghoul's stench for 1 minute.

action->Consume Flesh.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.ixPqVlqLaYTB1b23]
Consume Flesh
action->Consume Flesh.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.ixPqVlqLaYTB1b23]

The ghoul devours a chunk of a creature that died within the last hour and regains @Damage[1d6[healing]] Hit Points.

The ghoul can regain Hit Points from a given body only once.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: The ghoul stalker deals an extra 1d4 damage to creatures that have the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition.

action->Swift Leap.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.UU1Fp3PRuTFONjC9]
Swift Leap

Giant Ant (BB).name: Giant Ant (BB)
Giant Ant (BB).publicNotes: Giant ants form vast underground colonies, excavating deep burrows or infesting existing caverns. Giant ants look identical to their smaller kin, but their size makes them a deadly threat to farms and travelers alike.

action->Giant Ant Venom.name: Giant Ant Venom
action->Giant Ant Venom.description: A target that takes piercing damage from the giant ant's stinger Strike must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:18|traits:damaging-effect] save or take @Damage[1d10[poison]] damage.

action->Haul Away.name: Haul Away
action->Haul Away.description: If the giant ant has a creature grabbed or restrained with its mandibles, it can spend this action to Stride up to its speed, carrying the creature with it. At the end of the Stride, place the creature in any open square adjacent to the giant ant.

Giant Centipede (BB).name: Giant Centipede (BB)
Giant Centipede (BB).publicNotes:
Centipedes are relatively common arthropods that live, hunt, and scavenge amid dung and detritus. Scurrying about with surprising speed on the scores of legs attached to their long, segmented bodies, centipedes strike with poisoned mandibles.

Most giant centipedes (known as sewer centipedes when found in cities) nest in small groups but hunt alone. Attempts to domesticate giant centipedes to use as guardians or pets generally end poorly, but some goblin and kobold societies have developed effective methods of utilizing these vermin as guardians. Some societies roast and eat centipedes, often with pungent peppers, as a savory delicacy, although care must be taken in preparing the meal to avoid contaminating the flesh with the creature's venom.

action->Giant Centipede Venom.name: Giant Centipede Venom
action->Giant Centipede Venom.description: A target that takes piercing damage from the centipede's mandibles Strike must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:14] save or take @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage.

Giant Rat (BB).name: Giant Rat (BB)
Giant Rat (BB).publicNotes:
Giant rats are enormous versions of the common vermin. They're typically found in abundant numbers, but since they can't fit in the nooks where ordinary rats typically hide, they're much easier to locate and exterminate. In fact, finding and slaying a giant rat is a rite of passage for many an adventurer. Such tasks get tiresome quickly, so many veterans subcontract extermination to new adventurers.

Giant rats mostly live in sewers where they can scavenge from the streets above, but some families of giant rats live in more remote locations, such as dank caves, forests, or hills. Rats are incredibly adept survivors and can be found nearly anywhere in the world, though they tend to favor temperate or warm climates as opposed to cold regions.

Although their bite alone isn't lethal except to the very weak, some giant rats carry a dangerous disease common to rodents around the world-a pestilence more than capable of ravaging rural communities. The rats are merely carriers with no risk of succumbing to the disease themselves.

Giant Spider (BB).name: Giant Spider (BB)
Giant Spider (BB).publicNotes: Few everyday vermin inspire as much dread as the infamous spider. Giant spiders vary in size. The human-sized versions, sometimes called hunting spiders, are the most common type of giant spider, though not the largest.

action->Descend on a Web.name: Descend on a Web
action->Descend on a Web.description: The giant spider moves straight down up to 40 feet, suspended by a web line. It can hang from the web or drop off. The distance it Descends on a Web doesn't count for falling damage. A creature can Strike the web, which has AC 20 and 8 HP. If the web is reduced to 0 HP, the spider falls.

action->Giant Spider Venom.name: Giant Spider Venom
action->Giant Spider Venom.description: A target damaged by the spider's fangs must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:16] save or take @Damage[1d10[poison]] damage and gain the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition for 1 round.

action->Web Trap.name: Web Trap
action->Web Trap.description: A creature hit by the giant spider's web Strike gets stuck to the nearest surface. It can't move until it successfully @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escapes} (DC 17).

Giant Viper (BB).name: Giant Viper (BB)
Giant Viper (BB).publicNotes:
Snakes come in an array of forms, from jungle-dwelling constrictors that wrap around their prey to venomous vipers with deadly bites. Regardless, all snakes consume their prey whole by unhinging their jaws and using powerful muscles to move the food down their throats and into their stomachs.

The giant viper's fangs, nearly as long as daggers, easily inspire fear. The venom injected by a giant viper can cause severe blood clotting and inflict tremendous damage.

action->Coiled Opportunity.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.hFtNbo1LKYCoDy2O]
Coiled Opportunity
action->Coiled Opportunity.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.hFtNbo1LKYCoDy2O]

If the giant viper is coiled and a creature moves into or through a square adjacent to it, the giant viper can use its reaction to make a fangs Strike against that creature.

action->Coil.name: Coil
action->Coil.description: The giant viper uses an action to coil itself. While coiled, it can target a creature up to 10 feet away with its fangs Strike. After the giant viper Strikes with its fangs, it becomes uncoiled.

action->Giant Viper Venom.name: Giant Viper Venom
action->Giant Viper Venom.description: A target damaged by the snake's fangs must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:17] save or take @Damage[1d8[poison]] damage.

Goblin Commando (BB).name: Goblin Commando (BB)
Goblin Commando (BB).publicNotes:
Most goblin communities teeter in a state of barely controlled disarray-a collective of creatures operating largely on gut instinct rarely follows any clear direction. Even goblin leaders tend to be impulsive, irresponsible, and generally just not that good at actually leading.

In theory, goblin commandos lead goblin raids. In practice, goblin commandos rarely continue to lead their comrades once a battle has begun. Most shirk their responsibilities in favor of wading into the fray and claiming glory from their kin.

action->Goblin Scuttle.name: Goblin Scuttle
action->Goblin Scuttle.description: If a goblin ally ends a move action adjacent to the goblin commando, the commando can use their reaction to Step.

Goblin Igniter (BB).name: Goblin Igniter (BB)
Goblin Igniter (BB).publicNotes:
Goblins find fire totally fascinating. It makes light. It's great for cooking. It's a fun toy! Some goblins take their people's admiration of fire a little bit too far and into the realm of deadly obsession.

Goblins who turn their attentions to magic so they can learn to make fire from nothing are known as goblin igniters. These flame fanatics can be a great boon to a band of goblin raiders eager to torch their enemies and wreak havoc. More often, however, their presence is a double-edged sword. In the heat of the moment, goblin igniters sometimes lose sight of their goals and simply set fire to anything that will burn-including their own allies!

spell->Light.target: 1 object of 1 Bulk or less, either unattended or possessed by you or a willing ally

action->Goblin Scuttle.name: Goblin Scuttle
action->Goblin Scuttle.description: If a goblin ally ends a move action adjacent to the goblin igniter, the igniter can use their reaction to Step.

Goblin Warrior (BB).name: Goblin Warrior (BB)
Goblin Warrior (BB).publicNotes:
The frontline fighters of goblin tribes prefer to fight in large groups-especially when they can outnumber their foes by at least three to one. One doesn't need intense training or great toughness to become a goblin warrior. Anyone can aspire to this role, or be drafted into it during an emergency.

Goblin warriors delight in wreaking havoc. They think nothing of slaughtering livestock, stealing infants, or burning down buildings purely for momentary delight. They revel in playing malicious tricks on taller humanoids, whom they call "longshanks." What the goblins lack in consistency, long-term planning, and good sense, they make up for in sheer bravery and commitment.

action->Goblin Scuttle.name: Goblin Scuttle
action->Goblin Scuttle.description: If a goblin ally ends a move action adjacent to the goblin warrior, the warrior can use their reaction to Step.

Harpy (BB).name: Harpy (BB)
Harpy (BB).publicNotes: Harpies are an amalgamation of human and bird, using their ancestral control of the wind to lure prey or even directly pull in their next meal. Harpies can eat most creatures, but prefer to eat humans and elves in particular. Harpies live in family groups or larger clans, although they rarely hunt in big groups, preferring to keep most meals for themselves.

action->Stench.name: Stench
action->Stench.description: A creature that comes within 30 feet of the harpy and can smell the harpy must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:21] save. On a failure, the creature takes a -1 status penalty to all checks and DCs until it uses an action to retch. A creature that succeeds at its save isn't affected by any harpy's stenches for 1 minute.

action->Hungry Winds.name: Hungry Winds
action->Hungry Winds.description: The harpy uses the wind to pull its prey closer. A target within 20 feet must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:21] save or be pulled adjacent to the harpy. The harpy then makes a jaws strike against the target. If the target is pulled into the air and cannot fly, it falls as normal.

Hell Hound (BB).name: Hell Hound (BB)
Hell Hound (BB).publicNotes: Temperamental and quick to aggressive behavior, hell hounds are fiendish canines from a hellish plane. They're skilled hunters and can breathe supernatural gouts of flame from their maws. A hell hound's appearance leaves no doubts as to its infernal origins-flesh the color of burning pitch, teeth as sharp as any fiend's pitchfork, and a shroud of ever-burning hellfire are all trademark features. Though they can't speak, they understand Diabolic, the language of Hell.

action->Hellfire Breath.name: Hellfire Breath
action->Hellfire Breath.description:
The hell hound breathes flames that deal @Damage[4d6[fire]] damage to all creatures in a @Template[cone|distance:15]. Each affected creature must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:19|basic] save.

The hell hound can't use Breath Weapon again for [[/br 1d4 #Recharge Hellfire Breath]]{1d4 rounds}. If the hell hound would take fire damage or is the target of a fire effect, its Hellfire Breath recharges.

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The hell hound's jaws Strike deals 1d4 extra damage to creatures within reach of two of the hell hounds' allies.

Hidden Pit (BB).name: Hidden Pit (BB)
Hidden Pit (BB).description: A wooden trapdoor covers a 10-foot square pit that's 20 feet deep.
Hidden Pit (BB).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:12|traits:hazard|name:Remove the Trapdoor] to remove the trapdoor.
Hidden Pit (BB).stealth: (or @Check[perception|dc:0|traits:hazard] if the trapdoor is disabled or broken)

action->Pitfall.name: Pitfall
action->Pitfall.description: If a creature walks onto the trapdoor, that creature falls in unless it succeeds at a @Check[reflex|dc:16] save to grab hold of the edge. The pit is 20 feet deep, dealing @Damage[10[bludgeoning]] damage to anyone who falls to the bottom.

Hobgoblin Soldier (BB).name: Hobgoblin Soldier (BB)
Hobgoblin Soldier (BB).publicNotes: Hobgoblins are singularly devoted to war, and their entire civilization is built upon fostering and maintaining conflict while simultaneously proving their superiority in battle. Highly organized, they work efficiently and effectively in groups, whether that group is a small raiding party, a roving war band, or a fully regimented army. Physically, hobgoblins stand about as tall as humans and have gray, ashen skin.

weapon->Longsword.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.LJdbVTOZog39EEbi]

Longswords can be one-edged or two-edged swords. Their blades are heavy and they're between 3 and 4 feet in length.

shield->Shield.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.Yr9yCuJiAlFh3QEB]
Shield
shield->Shield.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.Yr9yCuJiAlFh3QEB]

A shield has 20 Hit Points. If a shield ever takes 10 damage or more, it becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6dNUvdb1dhToNDj3]{Broken}. A broken shield can't be used for @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.xjGwis0uaC2305pm]{Raise a Shield} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.jM72TjJ965jocBV8]{Shield Block}, but you can still @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.bT3skovyLUtP22ME]{Repair} it. If the shield loses all 20 Hit Points, it is completely destroyed.

action->Formation.name: Formation
action->Formation.description: When they're adjacent to at least two other allies, the hobgoblin soldier gains a +1 circumstance bonus to AC and saving throws.

action->Shield Block.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.m4HQ2o5aPxjXf2kY]

If they @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.xjGwis0uaC2305pm]{Raised a Shield} since their last turn, the hobgoblin can spend their reaction to block a Strike. Reduce the damage by 5, but the hobgoblin and the shield both take the remaining damage, possibly @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6dNUvdb1dhToNDj3]{Breaking} or destroying the shield.

action->Twisting Tail.name: Twisting Tail
action->Twisting Tail.description: When a creature within 10 feet uses a move action or leaves a square during a move action it's using, the dragon can use their reaction to make a tail Strike at the creature with a -2 penalty. If it hits, the creature stops moving in the square it was in when the dragon used this reaction.

action->Draconic Frenzy.name: Draconic Frenzy
action->Draconic Frenzy.description: The dragon makes two claw Strikes and one tail Strike in any order.

action->Draconic Momentum.name: Draconic Momentum
action->Draconic Momentum.description: When the dragon gets a critical success on a Strike, they recharge their Poison Breath.

action->Poison Breath.name: Poison Breath
action->Poison Breath.description:
The dragon breathes a toxic cloud that deals @Damage[5d6[poison]] damage in a @Template[cone|distance:30]. Each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:21|basic] save.

The dragon can't use their Poison Breath again for [[/br 1d4 #Recharge Poison Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

weapon->Staff.name: Staff
weapon->Staff.description: This long piece of wood can aid in walking and deliver a mighty blow.

action->Sneak Attack.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.AWvNPE4U0kEJSL1T]

Zolgran deals an extra 1d6 damage to creatures that have the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition.

Kobold Dragon Mage (Black, BB).name: Kobold Dragon Mage (Black, BB)
Kobold Dragon Mage (Black, BB).publicNotes: Kobolds are small, reptilian humanoids who are often seen in the service of more powerful creatures. They lurk in dark places, usually tunnels and mines. Kobold mages use magic to carry out their schemes, often in service of a dragon or other powerful creatures.

action->Scamper.name: Scamper
action->Scamper.description: If the kobold is adjacent to at least one enemy, the kobold Strides up to 30 feet and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against reactions triggered by this movement. The kobold must end this movement in a space that's not adjacent to any enemy.

Kobold Dragon Mage (Blue, BB).name: Kobold Dragon Mage (Blue, BB)
Kobold Dragon Mage (Blue, BB).publicNotes: Kobolds are small, reptilian humanoids who are often seen in the service of more powerful creatures. They lurk in dark places, usually tunnels and mines. Kobold mages use magic to carry out their schemes, often in service of a dragon or other powerful creatures.

action->Scamper.name: Scamper
action->Scamper.description: If the kobold is adjacent to at least one enemy, the kobold Strides up to 30 feet and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against reactions triggered by this movement. The kobold must end this movement in a space that's not adjacent to any enemy.

Kobold mages use magic to carry out their schemes, often in service of a dragon or other powerful creatures.

Kobold Dragon Mage (Red, BB).name: Kobold Dragon Mage (Red, BB)
Kobold Dragon Mage (Red, BB).publicNotes: Kobolds are small, reptilian humanoids who are often seen in the service of more powerful creatures. They lurk in dark places, usually tunnels and mines. Kobold mages use magic to carry out their schemes, often in service of a dragon or other powerful creatures.

Kobold Dragon Mage (White, BB).name: Kobold Dragon Mage (White, BB)
Kobold Dragon Mage (White, BB).publicNotes: Kobolds are small, reptilian humanoids who are often seen in the service of more powerful creatures. They lurk in dark places, usually tunnels and mines. Kobold mages use magic to carry out their schemes, often in service of a dragon or other powerful creatures.

action->Scamper.name: Scamper
action->Scamper.description: If the kobold is adjacent to at least one enemy, the kobold Strides up to 30 feet and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against reactions triggered by this movement. The kobold must end this movement in a space that's not adjacent to any enemy.

Kobold Scout (BB).name: Kobold Scout (BB)
Kobold Scout (BB).publicNotes: Most kobolds encountered outside of a well-defended warren or lair are kobold scouts, trained for stalking and the hunt. They're charged with bringing food and valuable goods back to the community. Kobolds are skilled at working together by necessity, and they often set up ambushes or hit-and-run assaults that allow them to do the most damage possible without putting themselves at much risk.

action->Scamper.name: Scamper
action->Scamper.description: If the kobold is adjacent to at least one enemy, the kobold Strides up to 30 feet and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against reactions triggered by this movement. The kobold must end this movement in a space that's not adjacent to any enemy.

action->Sneak Attack.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.AWvNPE4U0kEJSL1T]

The kobold scout deals an extra 1d6 damage to creatures that have the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition.

Kobold Trapmaster (BB).name: Kobold Trapmaster (BB)
Kobold Trapmaster (BB).publicNotes: Kobold trapmasters are the masterminds behind crafting and implementing wily traps in kobold lairs, and are widely respected among their kind.

weapon->Shortsword.name: Shortsword
weapon->Shortsword.description: These blades come in a variety of shapes and styles, but they are typically 2 feet long.

weapon->Spear.name: Spear
weapon->Spear.description: A long metal shaft ending with a metal spike, a spear can be used one-handed as a melee weapon and can be thrown.

armor->Leather Armor.name: Leather Armor
armor->Leather Armor.description: A mix of flexible and molded boiled leather, a suit of this type of armor provides some protection with maximum flexibility.

consumable->Spike Trap.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.3V2U720YhW2nyGVx]
Spike Trap
consumable->Spike Trap.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.3V2U720YhW2nyGVx]

This basic snare consists of hidden spikes that rely on a creature's momentum to lacerate or potentially impale it as it enters the snare's square, dealing 2d8 piercing damage. The creature must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:17|basic] saving throw.

action->Quick Trap.name: Quick Trap
action->Quick Trap.description:
The kobold trapmaster deploys one of their spike traps in an adjacent square.

Once this trap is deployed in a square, it deals @Damage[2d8[piercing]|name:Spike Trap] damage to anyone who steps on that square and they must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:17|basic] saving throw. A hero takes no damage on a critical success, half damage on a success, full damage on a failure, and double damage on a critical failure. These traps can be disabled with a successful @Check[thievery|dc:15|traits:action:disable-a-device] check.

action->Scamper.name: Scamper
action->Scamper.description: If the kobold is adjacent to at least one enemy, the kobold Strides up to 30 feet and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against reactions triggered by this movement. The kobold must end this movement in a space that's not adjacent to any enemy.

action->Sneak Attack.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.AWvNPE4U0kEJSL1T]

The kobold trapmaster deals an extra 1d6 damage to creatures that have the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition.

Kobold Warrior (BB).name: Kobold Warrior (BB)
Kobold Warrior (BB).publicNotes:
A typical kobold trains with simple weaponry. Kobolds are capable of landing sneaky strikes against unsuspecting foes, but they're just as quick to scamper off to safety if their group wouldn't outnumber their enemies by at least two to one.

Kobolds believe in pragmatism, and a defeated kobold would rather surrender than face death. One might even abandon their kobold kin and concede to serve the victor if the alternative is an untimely demise.

action->Scamper.name: Scamper
action->Scamper.description: If the kobold is adjacent to at least one enemy, the kobold Strides up to 30 feet and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against reactions triggered by this movement. The kobold must end this movement in a space that's not adjacent to any enemy.

action->Sneak Attack.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.AWvNPE4U0kEJSL1T]

The kobold warrior deals an extra 1d4 damage to creatures that have the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition.

Leopard (BB).name: Leopard (BB)
Leopard (BB).publicNotes: Leopards range from the iconic yellow with black spots to black panthers and white-furred, black-spotted snow leopards. Few predators can match their talent for stalking and stealth.

action->Maul.name: Maul
action->Maul.description: The leopard makes two claw Strikes against a creature it has @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}. The second attack uses the same multiple attack penalty as the first, but later attacks that turn take a -10 multiple attack penalty (or -8 for its claws).

action->Pounce.name: Pounce
action->Pounce.description: The leopard Strides and makes a Strike at the end of that movement. If the leopard successfully used @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.XMcnh4cSI32tljXa]{Hide} before this action, the target has the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition against this Strike.

action->Sneak Attack.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.AWvNPE4U0kEJSL1T]

The leopard deals an extra 1d4 damage to creatures that have the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition.

action->Grab.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.Tkd8sH4pwFIPzqTr]

When the leopard succeeds at its jaws Strike, it can use this action immediately after to attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} the target. This Grapple doesn't apply or count toward the leopard's multiple attack penalty.

Mermaid Fountain (BB).name: Mermaid Fountain (BB)
Mermaid Fountain (BB).disable:
@Check[thievery|dc:20|traits:complex,hazard|name:Disable Mechanism] on each corner mechanism (must disable all three working corners to disable the trap)

Each corner mechanism has hardness 8 and 15 HP
Mermaid Fountain (BB).routine:
Each turn, the fountain uses 1 action. Roll a [[/r 1d10]]{1d10} and look up the result on the following list to determine which action it uses that round.

  • 1-4 Single Target The statue spins about and sprays water at a single random target in the room. Roll a [[/r 1d4]]{1d4} and count to the number you rolled, starting with the player on your left, to determine which hero gets attacked. The spray is a ranged Strike.
  • 5-7 Corner Spray The statue spins about, firing a spray of water at each corner of the room that still has a functioning corner mechanism. This hits any creature adjacent to the corner mechanism, dealing @Damage[2d6[bludgeoning]] damage. Each hero must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|traits:hazard], taking no damage on a critical success, half damage on a success, full damage on a failure, and double damage on a critical failure.
  • 8-9 Half Room The statue spins about, spraying half of the room with water. Roll any die. If the result is even, it sprays the west half; otherwise, it sprays the east half. This deals @Damage[2d6[bludgeoning]] damage to each creature in that half of the room, and each hero must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|traits:hazard] save.
  • 10 Full Room This works just like the half-room attack, but it targets everyone in the room.

Mimic (BB).name: Mimic (BB)
Mimic (BB).publicNotes:
Thought to be the result of a failed experiment meant to animate objects or a sinister alghollthu creation, mimics are clever monsters that can take the form of common manufactured objects. Mimics are ambush predators and voracious eaters, surprising their prey through their uncanny ability to mimic the form of common furniture and miscellany. They remain disguised until unsuspecting adventurers happen by, then they lash out in ambush.

Mimics possess complex alien minds, and while often cruel and self-serving, they also enjoy conversation with their prey from time to time. For unknown reasons, they are especially interested in humanoids. Mimics have a strong dislike for others of their kind and tend to live alone. A mimic can remain in its alternate form for an extremely long period of time, sometimes remaining disguised in a dungeon chamber for decades. Regardless of how long it waits, the mimic remains vigilant and alert, ready to strike at any moment.

action->Adhesive.name: Adhesive
action->Adhesive.description: Any creature that touches the mimic (usually from a fist Strike, the mimic's pseudopod, or a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shove}) must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:23] save or gain the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} condition. The DC to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} is 23. A melee or thrown weapon that hits the mimic sticks to it. A character can spend an action to attempt a @Check[athletics|dc:23] check, removing the weapon on a success. The adhesive dissolves 1 minute after the mimic dies.

action->Object Lesson.name: Object Lesson
action->Object Lesson.description: If a creature touches the mimic while the mimic is transformed into an object, the mimic can spend its reaction to use its adhesive with no saving throw. The mimic then makes a pseudopod Strike. Object Lesson can't be used again until the mimic escapes and takes on a new disguise.

action->Mimic Object.name: Mimic Object
action->Mimic Object.description: The mimic assumes the shape of any Medium object. This alters its visual appearance but not its size. It takes a @Check[perception|dc:28] check to tell the object is a creature.

Minotaur Hunter (BB).name: Minotaur Hunter (BB)
Minotaur Hunter (BB).publicNotes: A minotaur is a large humanoid with a bovine head and hooves. Though often mistaken for aggressive brutes, many minotaurs are skilled artisans. Lone minotaurs tend to make their lairs within a maze or old ruin, hunting anyone who dares to invade their labyrinthine home.

action->Perfect Orienteering.name: Perfect Orienteering
action->Perfect Orienteering.description: A minotaur automatically critically succeeds on Survival checks to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.fJImDBQfqfjKJOhk]{Sense Direction} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EA5vuSgJfiHH7plD]{Track}.

action->Axe Swipe.name: Axe Swipe
action->Axe Swipe.description: The minotaur makes two Strikes with its greataxe against two adjacent enemies, both of whom are within its reach. The second attack uses the same multiple attack penalty as the first, but attacks it makes after this take a -10 multiple attack penalty.

action->Powerful Charge.name: Powerful Charge
action->Powerful Charge.description: The minotaur Strides twice, then makes a horn Strike. If the moved at least 20 feet from their starting position, the Strike's damage is increased to 2d8+10 piercing.

Ogre Warrior (BB).name: Ogre Warrior (BB)
Ogre Warrior (BB).publicNotes:
Ogres embody cruelty and brutish, amoral violence. Standing 10 feet tall and densely muscled, ogres are as strong as they are cruel. They typically enjoy remorseless violence in all of its forms. Although they prefer to vent their violent urges on smaller humanoids-the smaller, the better-ogres promise a horrifying fate for anyone unlucky enough to fall within their meaty grasp.

Always eager for mayhem and murder, ogre warriors are quick to turn on their kin when there's a shortage of smaller folk to torment, so those who lead ogres do their best to keep them constantly distracted with new opportunities for raids and ruin. An ogre's deficits in both patience and intelligence make them easy to trick, giving cunning captives many ways to get the better of them.

weapon->Greataxe.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.8COlYvHe6hKCXY8x]

This large battle axe is too heavy to wield with only one hand. Many greataxes incorporate two blades, and they are often "bearded", having a hook at the bottom to increase the strength of their chopping power.

Orc Commander (BB).name: Orc Commander (BB)
Orc Commander (BB).publicNotes: When orcs raid, the strongest is chosen as the leader. Bonds of blood are especially strong among orcs, and the mightiest orc holds are typically made up of siblings who have chosen a strong commander to protect their kinfolk.

action->Ferocity.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.N1kstYbHScxgUQtN]

When the orc is reduced to 0 Hit Points, they can use their reaction to remain conscious with 1 Hit Point, but they gain the wounded 1 condition (or increases the wounded value by 1 if they already have that condition). The orc can't use this ability at wounded 3.

action->Battle Cry.name: Battle Cry
action->Battle Cry.description:
Bellowing mightily, the commander gives themself and all orc allies within @Template[emanation|distance:60]{60 feet} who can hear them a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls until the start of the orc commander's next turn.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.Yqq4AkZ9lrm4CcID]{Effect: Battle Cry}

Orc Scrapper (BB).name: Orc Scrapper (BB)
Orc Scrapper (BB).publicNotes: Orcs are proud, strong humanoids that live by the rule that might makes right. They amass in warbands both large and small, conquering territory and robbing those unlucky enough to cross their path. Countless small settlements, outposts, and forts have fallen at the hands of orc raiders, whose sheer destructiveness leaves an indelible mark on the lands they conquer. The furious and undisciplined rankand-file scrappers make up the bulk of an orc warband.

action->Ferocity.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.N1kstYbHScxgUQtN]

When the orc is reduced to 0 Hit Points, they can use their reaction to remain conscious with 1 Hit Point, but they gain the wounded 1 condition (or increases the wounded value by 1 if they already have that condition). The orc can't use this ability at wounded 3.

Orc Veteran (BB).name: Orc Veteran (BB)
Orc Veteran (BB).publicNotes: The typical orc trooper is a violent combatant familiar to many adventurers. Orc warriors fight for their holds, for riches, and-perhaps most of all-for glory. Proving their own strength improves their station within their orc hold, so battle is a crucial part of life for any orc who aspires to one day lead or go down in history.

armor->Breastplate.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.r0ifJfoz8aqf0mwk]

Though referred to as a breastplate, this type of armor consists of several pieces of plate or half-plate armor that protect the torso, chest, neck, and sometimes the hips and lower legs. It strategically grants some of the protection of plate while allowing greater flexibility and speed.

action->Ferocity.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.N1kstYbHScxgUQtN]

When the orc is reduced to 0 Hit Points, they can use their reaction to remain conscious with 1 Hit Point, but they gain the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.Yl48xTdMh3aeQYL2]{Wounded 1} condition (or increases the wounded value by 1 if they already have that condition). The orc can't use this ability at wounded 3.

Owlbear (BB).name: Owlbear (BB)
Owlbear (BB).publicNotes: The owlbear is a territorial predator with the body of a brown bear but the head-and resultant keen senses-of an owl.

action->Bloodcurdling Screech.name: Bloodcurdling Screech
action->Bloodcurdling Screech.description: Each creature within @Template[emanation|distance:80]{80 feet} who can hear the owlbear's screech must attempt a @Check[will|dc:20] save. The creatures can't be affected by another screech for 1 minute. On a critical success, the creature is unaffected; on a success, the creature gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} condition; on a failure, the creature gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} condition; on a critical failure, the creature gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3} condition and must spend its next turn running away from the owlbear.

action->Screeching Advance.name: Screeching Advance
action->Screeching Advance.description: The owlbear makes a Bloodcurdling Screech and Strides twice. All creatures within @Template[emanation|distance:80]{80 feet} of the owlbear at any point during this movement are subjected to the effects of Bloodcurdling Screech.

action->Grab.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.Tkd8sH4pwFIPzqTr]

When the owlbear succeeds at its talon Strike, it can use this action immediately after to automatically give the target the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} condition until the end of its next turn.

Pugwampi (BB).name: Pugwampi (BB)
Pugwampi (BB).publicNotes: Gremlins are cruel fey tricksters and saboteurs who enjoy causing inventive destructiveness. Dog-faced pugwampis are craven, and they take great joy in the accidents and missteps caused by the ill fortune they magically project.

action->-2 Penalty on Perception to Hear.name: -2 Penalty on Perception to Hear things

action->Animal Talker.name: Animal Talker
action->Animal Talker.description: Pugwampis can talk to and understand animals.

action->Unluck Aura.name: Unluck Aura
action->Unluck Aura.description:
Creatures other than animals, gremlins, and kholo within @Template[emanation|distance:20]{20 feet} become extremely unlucky. They must attempt a @Check[will|dc:16] save, rolling this Will save twice and using the worse result.

On a successful save, the creature can't be affected by pugwampi unluck auras for 24 hours. On a failure, the creature must roll twice and use the worse result on all checks as long as it's within 20 feet of the pugwampi.

Multiple pugwampis don't create any increased effect.

Reefclaw (BB).name: Reefclaw (BB)
Reefclaw (BB).publicNotes: Reefclaws are aquatic monsters that resemble huge shrimp or lobsters. Though reefclaws can't speak, they are intelligent enough to understand the local language of humanoids near their hunting grounds.

action->Death Frenzy.name: Death Frenzy
action->Death Frenzy.description: When the reefclaw is reduced to 0 hit points it can spend this reaction to make a claw Strike before dying.

action->Constrict.name: Constrict
action->Constrict.description: If the reefclaw has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, it can spend one action to crush them in its coils. The creature takes @Damage[1d6[bludgeoning]] damage depending on its @Check[fortitude|dc:17|basic] save.

action->Reefclaw Venom.name: Reefclaw Venom
action->Reefclaw Venom.description: A target that takes slashing damage from the reefclaw's claw Strike must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:17|traits:damaging-effect] save or take @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage.

action->Grab.name: Grab
action->Grab.description: When the reeflclaw succeeds at its claw Strike, it can use this action immediately after to attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} the target. This Grapple doesn't apply or count toward the reefclaw's multiple attack penalty.

Scythe Blades (BB).name: Scythe Blades (BB)
Scythe Blades (BB).description: Two blades, each hidden in a 15-foot-long ceiling groove, are both connected to a trip wire.

action->Falling Scythes.name: Falling Scythes
action->Falling Scythes.description: When the trip wire is pulled or severed, both blades swing down, each one attacking all creatures under the ceiling grooves with a Scythe attack. The trap makes a Scythe melee attack with each blade. There's no multiple attack penalty on these attacks.

strike-melee->Scythe.name: Scythe
strike-melee->Scythe.description: No MAP applies to strikes made by scythe attacks

action->No MAP.name: No MAP
action->No MAP.description: The Scythe Strikes do not apply a MAP.

Sewer Ooze (BB).name: Sewer Ooze (BB)
Sewer Ooze (BB).publicNotes: These amorphous masses of sewage and detritus make their way through filthy culverts beneath cities. Some grow to enormous sizes and have insatiable appetites.

action->Motion Sense 60 feet.name: Motion Sense 60 feet
action->Motion Sense 60 feet.description: A sewer ooze can sense nearby motion through vibration and air movement, allowing it to fight as well as if it could see. However, a sewer ooze can't see, so effects that depend on vision or seeing don't work on it.

action->Filth Wave.name: Filth Wave
action->Filth Wave.description:
The sewer ooze unleashes a wave of filth, covering all creatures within 20 feet of itself. Each creature in the area must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:17|traits:damaging-effect] save or take @Damage[1d4[acid]] damage and a -10-foot penalty to its Speeds for 1 minute (on a critical failure, the creature also falls over and gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} condition). A creature can Interact to clean someone off. This decreases the Speed penalty to -5 feet after 1 action, or to no penalty after 2 actions. After using Filth Wave, the ooze can't use it again for 1 minute.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.Qomp2EujVCbzJb4X]{Effect: Filth Wave}

Shadow (BB).name: Shadow (BB)
Shadow (BB).publicNotes: Undead shadows feed on those who stray from the light.

action->Incorporeal.name: Incorporeal
action->Incorporeal.description: A shadow has no body and can pass through physical objects, though it can't end its turn inside one. Most checks that use Strength and require a body, such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shove}, don't work against a shadow, and a shadow can't use them.

action->Light Vulnerability.name: Light Vulnerability
action->Light Vulnerability.description: Attacks against the shadow are treated as magical if the shadow or the weapon being used is in light.

action->Shadow Spawn.name: Shadow Spawn
action->Shadow Spawn.description: When a creature's shadow is pulled free by Steal Shadow, it becomes a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-monster-core.Actor.clzHAfegb9Rn6DOe]{Shadow Spawn} under the command of the shadow that created it. This shadow spawn doesn't have Steal Shadow and is perpetually and incurably @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2}. If the creature the shadow spawn was pulled from dies, the shadow spawn becomes a full-fledged, autonomous shadow. If the creature recovers from its @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeeblement}, its shadow returns to it and the shadow spawn is extinguished.

action->Slink in Shadows.name: Slink in Shadows
action->Slink in Shadows.description: The shadow can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.XMcnh4cSI32tljXa]{Hide} or end its @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.VMozDqMMuK5kpoX4]{Sneak} in a creature's or object's shadow.

action->Steal Shadow.name: Steal Shadow
action->Steal Shadow.description: If the shadow hit a living creature with a Strike on its previous action, it can use this action to pull at the target's shadow, imposing a -1 status penalty to Athletics and to attack rolls and damage rolls that use Strength. The penalty increases each time a shadow uses this ability to a maximum of -4. The penalty decreases by 1 every hour.

Skeletal Giant (BB).name: Skeletal Giant (BB)
Skeletal Giant (BB).publicNotes: The reanimated bones of giants make excellent necromantic thralls, and the skeletal giants made out of bull-headed minotaurs are no exception. Mindless skeletons use similar tactics, so using a bigger, more durable skeleton is the only way a necromancer can obtain a more powerful thrall.

armor->Half Plate.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.pRoikbRo5HFW6YUB]

Half plate consists of most of the upper body plates used in full plate, with lighter or sparser steel plate protection for the arms and legs. This provides some of the protection of full plate with greater flexibility and speed. A suit of this armor comes with an undercoat of padded armor and a pair of gauntlets.

action->Broad Swipe.name: Broad Swipe
action->Broad Swipe.description: The skeletal giant makes two Strikes with its greataxe against two adjacent foes, both of whom are within its reach. The second attack uses the same multiple attack penalty as the first, but attacks it makes after this take a -10 multiple attack penalty (or a -8 multiple attack penalty for its horns).

action->Terrifying Charge.name: Terrifying Charge
action->Terrifying Charge.description:
The giant Strides and makes a horns Strike with a +4 circumstance bonus to damage.

If the strike hits, the giant attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2u915NdUyQan6uKF]{Demoralize} the target.

Skeleton Guard (BB).name: Skeleton Guard (BB)
Skeleton Guard (BB).publicNotes:
Made from bones held together by foul necromancy, skeletons can often be found haunting old dungeons and patrolling forgotten cemeteries. Many evil masterminds prefer to keep eternally vigilant undead as minions to avoid the upkeep required to feed and satisfy the psychological needs of living guardians.

Simple skeleton guards remain the most common skeletal minions. These skeletons are mindless, meaning they can't truly reason but can execute their basic guard duties of watching out for and attacking intruders. A group of several skeletons defending the same location usually consists of melee fighters and archers who shoot arrows from afar.

Slamming Door (BB).name: Slamming Door (BB)
Slamming Door (BB).description: Pressure-sensitive panels in the floor connect to a stone slab hidden in a hallway's ceiling.
Slamming Door (BB).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:15|traits:hazard|name:Disable Floor Panels] on the floor panels before the slab falls.

action->Slam Shut.name: Slam Shut
action->Slam Shut.description:
When pressure is placed on any floor tile, the door falls, closing off the hallway. The stone slab deals @Damage[3d8[bludgeoning]] damage to anyone beneath or adjacent to the slab when it drops and pushes them out of its space in a random direction. A creature that succeeds at a @Check[reflex|dc:17|traits:damaging-effect,hazard] save takes no damage and rolls out of the way in a random direction. On a critical success, they roll out of the way and can choose which direction.

Lifting the fallen slab requires a successful @Check[athletics|dc:25|traits:hazard] check. Hitting the floor panels triggers the trap. The slab uses the same AC and saves as the trap, but it has Hardness 12, HP 48 (BT 24).

Sod Hound (BB).name: Sod Hound (BB)
Sod Hound (BB).publicNotes:
Earth elementals such as sod hounds make excellent bodyguards for spelunkers and are ideal protectors of important subterranean locations. Coming from the Plane of Earth, they often appear in caverns deep underground.

Sod hounds take the form of mossy canines made of packed dirt and pebbles. They can band together with other sod hounds, traveling as a pack.

action->Crystal Sense 60 feet.name: Crystal Sense 60 feet
action->Crystal Sense 60 feet.description: A sod hound can sense crystals or gems within 60 feet.

action->Earth Glide.name: Earth Glide
action->Earth Glide.description: The sod hound burrows through any earthen matter, including rock. It moves up to 20 feet, leaving no tunnels or signs of its passing.

action->Knockdown.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.BCLvAx4Pz4MLa2pu]

When the sod hound succeeds at its jaws Strike, it can use this action immediately after to attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.ge56Lu1xXVFYUnLP]{Trip} the target. This Trip doesn't apply or count toward the sod hound's multiple attack penalty.

Spear Launcher (BB).name: Spear Launcher (BB)
Spear Launcher (BB).description: A wall socket loaded with a spear connects to a floor tile in one 5-foot square.
Spear Launcher (BB).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:18|traits:hazard|name:Disable Mechanism] on the floor tile or wall socket.

action->Spear.name: Spear
action->Spear.description: When pressure is applied to the floor tile, the trap shoots a spear, making an attack against the creature or object on the floor tile. The trap makes a ranged Spear attack.

Viper (BB).name: Viper (BB)
Viper (BB).publicNotes:
Each member of this family of venomous snakes has long, hinged fangs that inject potent venom into their prey. Different vipers inject different types of venom, which might result in paralysis, extreme pain and swelling, blood clotting, or even the sudden stopping of the victim's heart.

Though far less of an imposing physical threat than a giant viper, a common viper poses far more danger than its size would suggest. A viper mainly hunts small mammals or lizards but will attack a humanoid it perceives as a threat.

action->Slink.name: Slink
action->Slink.description: If a creature ends its movement adjacent to the viper or within the viper's space, the viper can use its reaction to Stride, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.c8TGiZ48ygoSPofx]{Swim} up to 10 feet. It must end its movement in a location that isn't within 5 feet of a foe. This movement doesn't trigger reactions.

action->Viper Venom.name: Viper Venom
action->Viper Venom.description: A target damaged by the viper's fangs must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:16] save or take @Damage[1d10[poison]] damage.

Warg (BB).name: Warg (BB)
Warg (BB).publicNotes: Wargs are often mistaken for wolves, but they have a cunning intelligence and the ability to speak. Wargs often form hunting parties with orcs and hobgoblins. Most wargs are amenable to this arrangement, but if food should run out, wargs are more than willing to integrate goblinoid flesh into their diet.

action->Avenging Bite.name: Avenging Bite
action->Avenging Bite.description: When a creature within the reach of the warg's bite attacks one of its allies, the warg can spend its reaction to make a jaws Strike against that creature.

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The warg's jaws Strike deals 1d4 extra damage to creatures within reach of two of the warg's allies.

action->Shred.name: Shred
action->Shred.description: If the warg has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, it can spend one action to shred them with its teeth. The creature takes @Damage[1d6[slashing]] damage and can make a @Check[fortitude|dc:18|basic] save.

action->Grab.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.Tkd8sH4pwFIPzqTr]

When the warg succeeds at its jaws Strike, it can use this action immediately after to attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} the target. This Grapple doesn't apply or count toward the warg's multiple attack penalty.

Web Lurker (BB).name: Web Lurker (BB)
Web Lurker (BB).publicNotes: Web lurkers, known also as ettercaps, are ugly monsters that not only dwell within the lairs of spiders and swarms, but actively cultivate and shepherd such vermin. Web lurkers hunt in forests, swamps, or scrubby hill lands. They construct structures from their webs high up in trees or within craggy, high canyons, and they surround their territory with traps constructed of the same webbing and natural material.

action->Spider Speak.name: Spider Speak
action->Spider Speak.description: The web lurker can speak with and understand spiders.

action->Web Lurker Venom.name: Web Lurker Venom
action->Web Lurker Venom.description: A target damaged by the web lurker's fangs must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:19] save or take @Damage[1d12[poison]] damage and gain the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} condition for 1 round.

action->Web Trap.name: Web Trap
action->Web Trap.description: A creature hit by the web lurker's web attack gets stuck to the nearest surface. It can't move until it successfully @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escapes} (DC 20).

Wight (BB).name: Wight (BB)
Wight (BB).publicNotes: Wights are undead humanoids that lurk in burial grounds, catacombs, or other places of the dead.

action->Final Spite.name: Final Spite
action->Final Spite.description: When the wight is reduced to 0 Hit Points, it can use its reaction to make a Strike before being destroyed. It doesn't gain any Hit Points from corrupting spite on this Strike.

action->Corrupting Spite.name: Corrupting Spite
action->Corrupting Spite.description:
When the wight deals damage to a living creature with its claw or dagger Strike, the wight regains @Damage[2[void,healing]|shortLabel] Hit Points and the target must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:17] save or take 2 damage that can't be healed. The wight can use corrupting spite multiple times, but a single creature can't take more than 8 unhealable damage.

Each full night of rest heals 2 of the unhealable damage, and a full day of bed rest increases the recovery to 4 of the unhealable damage.

Wolf (BB).name: Wolf (BB)
Wolf (BB).publicNotes: Wolves roam forests, hills, and other wild lands, where they live and hunt in packs. Contrary to popular belief, these packs aren't led by the strongest in the group, but typically consist of a mated pair, their pups, and juvenile offspring from previous mating seasons. Offspring generally leave their parents' pack upon reaching maturity, at which point they seek out mates of their own to form their own packs elsewhere. Wolves don't typically view humanoids as prey animals, but extraordinary circumstances can lead wolves to attack people, especially in winter months and other situations where traditional prey (such as deer and elk) are scarce.

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The wolf's jaws Strike deals 1d4 extra damage to creatures within reach of two of the wolf's allies.

action->Knockdown.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.BCLvAx4Pz4MLa2pu]

When the wolf succeeds at its jaws Strike, it can use this action immediately after to attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.ge56Lu1xXVFYUnLP]{Trip} the target. This Trip doesn't apply or count toward the wolf's multiple attack penalty.

Xulgath Leader (BB).name: Xulgath Leader (BB)
Xulgath Leader (BB).publicNotes: Xulgath leaders exhibit greater strength and more affinity for violence than other members of a xulgath community.

weapon->Greataxe.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.8COlYvHe6hKCXY8x]

This large battle axe is too heavy to wield with only one hand. Many greataxes incorporate two blades, and they are often "bearded", having a hook at the bottom to increase the strength of their chopping power.

armor->Breastplate.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.r0ifJfoz8aqf0mwk]

Though referred to as a breastplate, this type of armor consists of several pieces of plate or half-plate armor that protect the torso, chest, neck, and sometimes the hips and lower legs. It strategically grants some of the protection of plate while allowing greater flexibility and speed.

action->Stench.name: Stench
action->Stench.description: A creature that comes within @Template[emanation|distance:30] of the xulgath and can smell the xulgath must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:19] save. On a failure, the creature takes a -1 status penalty to all checks and DCs until it uses an action to retch. A creature that succeeds at its save isn't affected by any xulgaths' stenches for 1 minute (Use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}).

action->Swipe.name: Swipe
action->Swipe.description: The xulgath boss makes two Strikes with their greataxe against two adjacent foes, both of whom are within their reach, with a +1 circumstance bonus. The second attack uses the same multiple attack penalty as the first, but attacks the xulgath boss makes after this take a -10 multiple attack penalty (or a -8 multiple attack penalty for its claw).

Xulgath Warrior (BB).name: Xulgath Warrior (BB)
Xulgath Warrior (BB).publicNotes: Reptilian humanoids living underground, xulgaths (known as troglodytes to many surface dwellers) attack intruders in their territory on sight. They live in familial communities, battling rival groups and other aggressive underground inhabitants to survive. They occasionally raid surface settlements, usually at the behest of cruel, bloodthirsty leaders. A typical xulgath has dull gray, dark gray, or ashen scales with a long tail and bony protrusions down the length of their spine.

action->Stench.name: Stench
action->Stench.description: A creature that comes within @Template[emanation|distance:30] of the xulgath and can smell the xulgath must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:16] save. On a failure, the creature takes a -1 status penalty to all checks and DCs until it uses an action to retch. A creature that succeeds at its save isn't affected by any xulgaths' stenches for 1 minute (Use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}).

Zephyr Hawk (BB).name: Zephyr Hawk (BB)
Zephyr Hawk (BB).publicNotes:
Air elementals, such as a zephyr hawk, appear in a variety of sizes and shapes. From the Plane of Air, zephyr hawks are often summoned to be used as airborne messengers. Air elementals can also arrive spontaneously during powerful storms and tornadoes where elemental vortexes form.

Zephyr hawks appear to be made of clouds, with distinct shapes that give them the appearance of having the wings and beaks of birds. When one sees clouds that resemble animals, they're often unknowingly observing air elementals. Zephyr hawks sometimes drift among wind currents in great flocks called casts.

action->Circling Attack.name: Circling Attack
action->Circling Attack.description: The zephyr hawk flies up to half its Speed, makes two wing Strikes, then flies up to half its Speed again to return to its original location. The second half of this movement doesn't trigger reactions like Reactive Strike. The second attack uses the same multiple attack penalty as the first, but attacks it makes after this take a -8 multiple attack penalty.

Zombie Shambler (BB).name: Zombie Shambler (BB)
Zombie Shambler (BB).publicNotes: A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed. Among the living dead, zombies are most often used as fodder, wearing down defenses before more powerful undead arrive to deal the killing blow. Zombies can't truly think for themselves, but they can be commanded by other allied undead and powerful necromancers.

strike-melee->Jaws.name: Jaws
strike-melee->Jaws.description: Requirements The zombie has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}.

action->Slow.name: Slow
action->Slow.description: A zombie has only 2 actions on its turn, and it can't use reactions.
